content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Locate a hotel in Melbourne offering free parking and free WiFi, for a stay from February 28 to March 4, 2024.  Please interact with https://www.booking.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The first step to find a hotel in Melbourne is to enter the destination in the "Where are you going?" textbox.
Action: Type [14]; Melbourne
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination is currently set to "Niagara Falls". I need to update it to "Melbourne" as required in the task. The next step is to enter "Melbourne" in the destination field.
Action: Type [13]; Melbourne
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently displaying dates for September and October 2025, but the task requires setting the dates from February 28 to March 4, 2024. I need to navigate to the correct range by going back several months.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is showing dates for September and October 2025, but I need February/March 2024. There is a "Next month" button, but I need an option to go backward or quickly navigate to earlier dates, possibly by scrolling or finding a previous/back button (not visible yet). I need to scroll to see more of the calendar navigation options.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is still no visible button to go back to previous months, and the calendar is stuck on September/October 2025. The current interface does not show an obvious option for going backward; perhaps interacting with the calendar widget or checking alternative navigation could reveal more options.
Action: Click [15]
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now closed and the results page for Niagara Falls is displayed. I still need to correct the destination to Melbourne and set the proper dates. The destination field is now editable and available.
Action: Type [13]; Melbourne
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is open again and displaying months in the future (September/October 2025). There is only a "Next month" button visible, and still no clear way to quickly move backward. The interface may require scrolling up further or looking for a "previous month" arrow to reach February/March 2024.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar still only shows a "Next month" button and no visible way to move backward to the required dates (February/March 2024). There could be a left arrow or "Previous month" button off screen, or it might appear if scrolled further up or to the left.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar still does not display a way to go to previous months. Only the "Next month" button (18) for advancing forward is visible. There is no visible left-arrow or previous-month button, even after scrolling up. It's possible that interacting with another calendar element or changing the destination first will reset the calendar to a usable state for February/March 2024.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Where are you going?" search box (13) is now open and ready for a new location. I need to type "Melbourne" to set the correct destination as required by the task.
Action: Type [13]; Melbourne
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: After typing "Melbourne," the page returned to the calendar, but the destination field (13) still shows "Niagara Falls." The calendar remains set on September/October 2025. It appears that typing "Melbourne" in the previous step did not register or select it. I may need to actually select "Melbourne" from a dropdown (if available) or ensure the change is applied. I'll try clicking the search/button next to the textbox (14) to force the destination update.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination suggestion dropdown is visible, but “Melbourne” is not listed. I need to type “Melbourne” into the textbox (13) to set the correct destination for the search.
Action: Type [13]; Melbourne
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3

Confidence: 0.95
